content: {{knowledge objective |Identifiant=OIC-049-10-A |Item_parent=Normal and pathological puberty |Item_parent_short=Normal and pathological puberty |Rank=A |Title=Knowing the data from the interview and clinical examination pointing to precocious puberty |Description=None |Rubric=Positive diagnosis |Contributors= |Order=10}} '''Questioning data:''' pubertal ages of parents and siblings, age at menarche of mother, parental heights with calculation of genetic target height, family or personal history (IUGR, neurological history, adoption, neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1)), visual signs or signs of HTIC (headache, nausea, morning vomiting), analysis of growth rate (curve). Clinical examination: Complete examination, pubertal stage (Tanner), skin spots, signs of hyperandrogenism (acne, hirsutism, hyperseborrhoea, clitoral hypertrophy).

question.question: What is a key factor in diagnosing precocious puberty?
question.option_a: Analysis of growth rate (curve) and pubertal stage (Tanner) alone
question.option_b: Family or personal history (IUGR, neurological history, adoption, neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1)) and visual signs or signs of HTIC (headache, nausea, morning vomiting)
question.option_c: Parental heights with calculation of genetic target height and pubertal ages of parents and siblings
question.option_d: Age at menarche of mother and skin spots alone
